COMMENT_TX: $Phil Rizzuto followed Mickey Grasso towards dugout objecting to his slide; both dugouts emptied but 2B umpire Eddie Hurley got between the 2 players

$420 feet to Yankee bullpen
Debut game for Andy Carey
Protest=H
$Mickey Mantle out on appeal for missing 3B on an apparent RBI single
$Phil Rizzuto called for interference for blocking Jerry Priddy's view; Yankees manager Casey Stengel protested the game

ej,richp101,M,berrc103,Ordering pitch while batter out of box ej,rogos101,P,berrc103,Ordering pitch while batter out of box $Nelli Fox disputed a strike call by HP umpire Charlie Berry on 3-0 pitch; Fox continued to argue so Berry directed Tom Morgan to pitch and called strike 2; Fox continued to argue on one side of Berry and White Sox manager Paul Richards on the other side so Berry directed Morgan to pitch and called strike 3; Richards and Saul Rogovin ejected by Berry
$Tom Morgan left with torn fingernail
$Johnny Sain struck on kneecap by line drive
$Bob Cerv crashed into fence trying to catch homer and was knocked unconscious
$Tom Morgan left with blister
$Joe Collins left with 'Charley Horse' in left thigh
$Gil McDougald broke for 2B, Gus Niarhos threw back to Mickey McDermott, who wheeled and picked Gene Woodling off 3B
$Faye Throneberry called for interference for running into his own batted ball

fan interference

ej,garvn102,P,papaj901,Fan interference Ned Garver ejected by 3B umpire Joe Paparella for yelling about the fan interference; Garver was scheduled to start game two; Browns manager Rogers Hornsby tried to protest the game but it was not allowed because another pitch had been thrown after the interference call; Browns owner Bill Veeck called the press box from St. Louis and talked with his traveling secretary, telling him to tell Hornsby to protest
ej,peskj101,P,robbs901,Call at 2B $Gil McDougald stole while Billy Hoeft off rubber with ball; Johnny Pesky ejected by 2B umpire Scotty Robb
$Ferris Fain headed towards mound after brushback but was restrained by the umpires
$Phil Rizzuto called for interference for running into his own batted ball
$Billy Goodman and Sammy White collided; Goodman was knocked unconscious, but he held onto the ball

$there was originally a doubleheader scheduled for this afternoon, but heavy rains washed it out; This was Boston's last trip to New York in 1952, and the clubs already had a makeup game the following day, which meant that the clubs had three games left to play in only two days; therefore, the Yankees hastily scheduled a game for this night, and a day/night doubleheader for the following day; the conditions at game time were poor, but the forecast said they would improve; this was the first Labor Day night game in major league history
